item.title: Bets Emerge That End to Powell’s Term Means More Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: The prospect of a shift in US monetary policy when President Donald Trump replaces Jerome Powell at the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair in May 2026 has interest-rate traders looking for pay dirt.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Thomas Laubach Research Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. Powell said policymakers are weighing changes to key parts of the framework that guides their monetary policy decisions, including how they think about shortfalls in US employment and approach their inflation target.

item.title: Dutch Cabinet Approves NATO’s 5% Defense Spending Target
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof’s caretaker cabinet agreed to increase defense and security spending to 5% of gross domestic product by 2032 in line with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s proposed target.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: People wait in line at the Binnenhof in The Hague.

item.title: Israel-Iran Conflict Risks More Inflation, Delayed Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Israel’s attacks on Iran’s nuclear facilities risk pushing back the timeline for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts as the US central bank waits to assess any potential impact on inflation, economists said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Rescue workers survey the damage to buildings following Israeli airstrikes in Tehran, on June 13.

item.title: Starmer Signals Support for 3.5% NATO Aim With Talks on Date
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer indicated that the UK was prepared to endorse a new NATO target committing 3.5% of members’ economic output to core defense spending, although he emphasized that key details such as the timeline were still being negotiated.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: United Kingdom soldiers storm an enemy position in a simulated attack during the NATO military exercise in Drawsko Pomorskie, Poland.

item.title: Germany’s Klingbeil to Support Push to End EU Capital-Markets Impasse
item.description: German Finance Minister and Vice Chancellor Lars Klingbeil said he’ll support a push to try to break a deadlock on a decade-old European Union effort to deepen the bloc’s capital markets.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Rauwald, Isolde MacDonogh

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil, Germany's finance minister, at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Germany's economy is facing a third year without growth as businesses struggle with uncertainty around global trade, according to the Bundesbank.

item.title: Indian Tax Authorities Chasing Unreported Crypto Transactions
item.description: Indian tax authorities are investigating tax evasion and money laundering by “high-risk persons” through cryptocurrency, a government official said Friday.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: RF Cropped shot of woman's hand typing on computer keyboard in the dark, working late on laptop at home Photographer: d3sign/Moment RF

item.title: Oil Tanker Market Roiled by Israeli Airstrikes Against Iran
item.description: Israel’s overnight airstrikes on Iran drove up freight rates and tanker stocks Friday as traders and investors priced in the prospect of disruption to a large swath of the global oil-shipping fleet.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon, Alaric Nightingale

item.title: Keir Starmer Says UK Is Luring Top Talent Even as Non-Doms Leave
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he wants to attract more investors to Britain, even as the nation contends with an exodus of wealthy individuals because of tax hikes.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Stupples, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer speaks with tech apprentices at Downing Street in London.

item.title: Starmer Says UK Has ‘Grave Concerns’ on Iran Nuclear Program
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the UK has “grave concerns” about Iran’s nuclear program and backed Israel’s right to self-defense, while calling for de-escalation in a conflict that risks engulfing the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer in London, on June 13. Photographer: Tom Skipp/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Says No Obstacles Left in Finishing US-UK Trade Deal
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said there are no “hiccups or obstacles” remaining in the way of finalizing a trade deal with the US and indicated that an agreement would likely come soon.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers and dockside cranes at London Gateway port, operated by DP World Plc, in Stanford-le-Hope, UK, on Monday, Oct. 7, 2024. DP World spent £300 million ($366 million) on a fourth berth at its London Gateway container hub.

item.title: US Consumer Sentiment Jumps as Inflation Expectations Improve
item.description: US consumer sentiment rose by the most since January 2024 as concerns about the economy eased and short-term inflation expectations showed a marked improvement.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: An Aldi supermarket in Alhambra, California.

item.title: Netherlands Picks Sleijpen to Succeed Knot at Central Bank
item.description: The Dutch government appointed Olaf Sleijpen to head the central bank, sticking with an insider for the traditionally hawkish institution.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob, Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Olaf Sleijpen Source: De Nederlandsche Bank

item.title: Trump Ripping Up the Free Trade Playbook Comes With $1 Trillion Cost
item.description: The ominous trajectory of the US president’s tariff overhaul looms over the G-7 gathering.

media:content.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel deliberated with US President Donald Trump and others at the 2018 G-7 summit in Charlevoix, Canada—the last time Canada was the host country.

item.title: Japan’s Kato Says Talks With Markets Key for Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan’s Finance Minister said that discussions with market participants is a key factor in making sure that government bonds are bought and sold stably, as the ministry neared a closely watched gathering with investors.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Katsunobu Kato Photographer: Shoko Takayasu/Bloomberg

item.title: US Corporate Profit Fat Offers Cushion for Absorbing Tariffs
item.description: I’m Ben Holland, an economics editor in Washington. Today we’re looking at the implications for inflation from US corporate profit margins. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Ben Holland

item.title: Wrecking Ball Trump Makes the G-7 More Necessary
item.description: The upcoming conclave in Canada may be the rare space to find common ground, even as the forum itself is looking increasingly outmoded.
item.dc:creator: Lionel Laurent

media:content.media:description: A seat at a too-small table: US President Donald Trump and other G-7 leaders at the 2019 summit in Biarritz, France.

item.title: UK Household Inflation Expectations Fell Before April CPI Spike
item.description: UK households had been expecting inflation to slow over the coming year, according to a Bank of England survey that was conducted before the sudden jump in consumer prices reported last month.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on the high street in Maidstone. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: PSP Hunts for More Canada Deals as Assets Surge to $220 Billion
item.description: Canada’s Public Sector Pension Investment Board is looking to deploy more capital in its home country after years of global expansion that has pushed its investment portfolio to C$300 billion ($220 billion).
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Layan Odeh

media:content.media:description: Deborah Orida, president and chief executive officer of PSP Investments, during an event at The Canadian Club in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Monday, May 6, 2024. The Public Sector Pension Investment Board (PSP Investments) is one of Canada's largest pension investors.

item.title: No Clarity for Fed Until at Least September, Economists Say
item.description: It will take months yet before the Federal Reserve can get a clear idea of how Trump administration policy changes will shape the US economy, making officials unlikely to consider a change to interest rates before September, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro, Dana Morgan

item.title: Unrest Grips Bolivia as Dollar Crisis Sends Inflation Soaring
item.description: Lea en español
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: People wait in line to get some cooking oil on a street in La Paz, Bolivia, on June 4, 2025. A shortage of cooking oil in Bolivia has forced the rationing of up to 2 liters per person amid the country's ongoing economic crisis. The government attributes this to speculation and blames producers and sellers for hiding certain basic products, such as oil.

item.title: Huelgas y crisis del dólar llevan la inflación en Bolivia a un récord
item.description: Read the story in English
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: People wait in line to get some cooking oil on a street in La Paz, Bolivia, on June 4, 2025. A shortage of cooking oil in Bolivia has forced the rationing of up to 2 liters per person amid the country's ongoing economic crisis. The government attributes this to speculation and blames producers and sellers for hiding certain basic products, such as oil.

item.title: South Africa Rail Firm Averts Strike as Unions Accept Deal
item.description: South Africa’s state-owned ports and freight-rail company reached a pay deal with its two recognized labor unions, averting a strike that threatened to disrupt mineral and agricultural exports.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A freight locomotive pulls wagons from the Transnet Pyramid South Depot in Gauteng, South Africa, on Friday, Nov. 17, 2023. Volumes of goods and commodities, including iron ore and coal shipped through the Transnet’s freight rail network for export, have dropped because of issues including vandalism, idle locomotives and cable theft. Photographer: Guillem Sartorio/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Chief Economist Downplays Fears of Investment Fallout From ‘Revenge Tax’
item.description: The White House’s chief economist dismissed concerns that a controversial provision in President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill would drive away foreign bond investors, calling such fears a “misinterpretation.”
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Korea’s Lee Urges Chaebols to Quell Distrust, Hears Trade Fears
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung called on the heads of the country’s largest conglomerates to help restore market trust while hearing out their concerns over the impact of Donald Trump’s tariffs on global trade.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Shinhye Kang

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung

item.title: China’s Economy Withstood Trade Chaos But Momentum Likely Slowed
item.description: The Chinese economy rode out the tariff rollercoaster in May even as domestic consumption likely weakened again, after the government’s massive fiscal stimulus and frontloading by exporters offset shocks from abroad.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: India, US Harden Trade Stance as July Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: Trade officials from India and the US have hardened their stance on some key issues as they race to conclude an interim deal before higher US tariffs take effect in July, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Israeli Attack on Iran Raises Risk of Wider Conflict, Bloomberg Economics Says
item.description: Israel’s attack on the Iranian nuclear program and its ballistic missile sites threatens to spark wider fighting in the Middle East that risks drawing in the US, according to Bloomberg Economics.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann

media:content.media:description: TEHRAN, IRAN - JUNE 13: A building in Nobonyad Square is shown having suffered significant damage in Israeli airstrikes on June 13, 2025 in Tehran, Iran. (Photo by Majid Saeedi/Getty Images)

item.title: Caller ID Is Destroying Our Understanding of the Jobs Market
item.description: Britain’s statistics crisis is not unique — modern technology and changing habits are causing problems in many countries
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Molly Smith, Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Changing social habits are one of many obstacles facing statistics offices around the world.

item.title: BOJ Is Said to See Inflation Running Stronger Than Expected
item.description: Bank of Japan officials see prices rising a little stronger than they expected earlier in the year, a factor that may open the door to discussions over whether to raise interest rates if global trade tensions ease, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its monetary policy settings steady as it bides its time for now, while a dissenter's proposed rate hike suggests momentum for another increase is building.

item.title: A $115 Billion Fund Manager Bets on Shortest Maturity India Debt
item.description: India’s economic growth is set to accelerate sharply, making the ultra short-end of the debt market the most attractive segment, according to one of the country’s top money managers.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Malavika Kaur Makol

media:content.media:description: Manish Banthia Source: ICICI Prudential Asset Management Ltd.
